text:
Marmeladov got his habit of giving long speeches from talking to strangers at the tavern. For some drinkers, this habit becomes a need, especially if they are kept in check at home. When they are with other drinkers, they try to explain themselves and get some respect.

The innkeeper said, "What a funny guy! Why don’t you work? Why aren’t you doing your job if you have one?"

Marmeladov answered, talking only to Raskolnikov as if he asked the question. "Why am I not at my job? It hurts my heart to think how useless I am. A month ago, when Mr. Lebeziatnikov hit my wife and I was drunk, didn’t I suffer? Excuse me, young man, have you ever had to ask for a loan, knowing you won’t get it?"

"Yes, I have. But what do you mean by hopelessly?" Raskolnikov asked.

"Hopelessly means you know for sure you won’t get anything. You know that this man, who seems very respectable, will never give you money. And why should he? He knows I can’t pay it back. Out of kindness? But Mr. Lebeziatnikov, who follows the latest ideas, said that nowadays, science says kindness is not allowed. That’s what they do in England, where they study economics. Why, I ask..."

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Marmeladov reflects on the despair of beggary and the hopelessness of seeking help from others while grappling with his own failures and the consequences of his alcoholism.
